Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 46193-001 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
Addressing Knowledge and Statistical Gaps in 
Relation to Poverty Reduction, Inequality, and 
Inclusive Growth
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB‘s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  ERDI  –  Development Indicators and Policy Research Division 
  MPI  –  multidimensional poverty index 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UNDP  –  United Nations Development Programme 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Public  sector  management  (economic  and  public  affairs 
management) 
Theme (subtheme)  –  Social development (human development) 
Location (impact)  –  Regional (high), national (high) 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, ―$‖ refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  B. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
Assistant Chief  D. Brooks, Development Indicators and Policy Research Division, ERD 
Economist 
   
Team leader  G. Wan, Principal Economist, ERD 
Team members  A. Andrysiak, Statistician, ERD 
  I. Sebastian-Samaniego, Economics and Statistics Analyst, ERD 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status  
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Poverty reduction is the first indicator of the Millennium Development Goals and the 
overarching goal of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Despite fast economic growth, Asia 
and the Pacific remains home to almost two-thirds of the world‘s poor. The region is also 
confronted  with  rising  inequality.  Its  Gini  coefficient,  the  most  commonly  used  inequality 
measure, increased from 0.39 in the mid-1990s to 0.46 in the late 2000s.1 Reducing poverty 
and promoting inclusive growth are major challenges faced by developing member countries 
(DMCs), donors, the development community, and ADB. 
 
2.  Transparent, reliable, timely, and comparable estimates of poverty and inequality are 
essential for a wide range of decisions national governments and development institutions make. 
They also lay the foundation for poverty and inclusive growth-related research. For example, 
ADB Management often quotes the total number of poor in the region in speeches, and both 
donors and DMCs appealed for poverty updates before the recent Asian Development Fund 
replenishment negotiation.2 
 
3.  This technical assistance (TA) aims to (i) measure and monitor poverty and inequality 
regularly for individual DMCs and for the region as a whole; (ii) conduct poverty, inequality, and 
inclusive growth-related research; and (iii) develop a website to disseminate relevant estimates 
and knowledge products, which are expected to aid evidence-based policy formulation.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  While some DMCs release poverty estimates, the main issue lies in comparability across 
countries. In addition to different reference years, national poverty estimates are often computed 
using different methodologies including different poverty lines and even different variables—
making aggregation impossible. For comparable estimates and regional aggregates, ADB has 
relied on the World Bank for poverty estimation and monitoring, although in 2011 the ADB 
Economics and Research Department (ERD) provided poverty updates for Asian Development 
Fund replenishment negotiations. However, three major problems exist with the World Bank 
poverty estimates: (i) lack of transparency, e.g., the World Bank does not provide information on 
the sources of data for all countries; (ii) long delay in updates, e.g., until middle of February 
2012, the only available comprehensive poverty estimates from the World Bank were for 2005, 
which for a dynamic region such as Asia and the Pacific is inadequate and more timely updates 
are called for; and (iii) the analytical method used by the World Bank to produce poverty 
estimates from grouped data is problematic, which requires rectification.4 
 
5.  Income-based inequalities have been increasing in Asia and the Pacific. Inclusive growth 
is one of the three pillars of ADB‘s operations, as outlined in its Strategy 2020.5 However, little 
systematic information or data on inequalities for the region as a whole are available. Thus,

2   
there is a need to estimate income-based, and if possible non-income-based, measures of 
inequalities for the region and for individual DMCs. These estimates represent potential building 
blocks for developing inclusive growth indicators. 
 
6.  Related  to  non-income-based  inequality  is  analysis  of  poverty  along  non-income 
dimensions.  Deprivations  in  health,  education,  and  other  social  development  indicators 
increasingly attract the attention of development agencies and policy makers. The region‘s 
progress in non-income poverty reduction may lag behind the income-based counterpart. This 
has  profound  implications  for  both  donors  and  aid-recipient  DMCs.  The  United  Nations 
Development Programme (UNDP) has been producing multidimensional poverty index (MPI) 
estimates since 2010 but related research such as determinants of multidimensional poverty 
and its changes remains scarce. Analysis on non-income poverty or MPI estimates needs to be 
expanded. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA‘s intended impact is to improve the effectiveness of DMCs‘ policies and ADB‘s 
projects and programs aimed at reducing poverty and inequality and promoting inclusive growth. 
In the absence of knowledge on poverty and inequality and their changes, it is hardly possible to 
design, implement, or evaluate relevant interventions or policies. 
 
8.  The TA‘s expected outcome is more evidence-based policy-making by ADB and DMCs. 
Regular and systematic updates on poverty, inequality, and inclusive growth help enhance 
evidence-based policy making. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will consist of three components: poverty and inequality estimation; research on 
poverty, inequality, and inclusive growth; and construction of a website. 
 
10.  The  first  component  will  focus  on  estimating  income-based  poverty  and  inequality. 
Poverty estimation will rely on the international $1.25 per day, $2.00 per day, and possibly Asian 
and/or relative poverty lines. Purchasing power parity exchange rates and the consumer price 
index will be used to ensure comparability of poverty estimates across economies and over 
time. In addition to the number of poor, other poverty indicators such as poverty gap and 
squared poverty gap will be estimated. 
 
11.  Income-based inequality estimates for the region as a whole may have to use per capita 
GDP data but those for individual DMCs can use household survey observations on average 
income or expenditure. Demographic and health survey data may be used to estimate non-
income-based poverty and inequality. Inequality indexes such as the Gini coefficient and the 
generalized entropy measures will be employed. 
 
12.  The second component will focus on the development of inclusive growth indicators at 
the country level, possibly using a social welfare function approach. Summary measures of 
inclusive growth will be constructed. These summary measures will complement and build upon 
the framework of inclusive growth indicators of the Development Indicators and Policy Research 
Division  (ERDI)  of the ADB  ERD,  which  presents tabulation  of 35  indicators. The  second 
component will also explore the determinants and consequences or effects of high poverty and

3 
rising inequality, using various decomposition techniques and econometric modeling. Provided 
that data are available, poverty can be decomposed by location, sector, population groups, and 
so  on.  It  can  also  be  decomposed  into  transient  and  chronic  components.  In  addition, 
vulnerability to poverty will be investigated for selected DMCs. To differentiate from UNDP‘s MPI 
estimates, multidimensional  poverty  measurement  will  employ  Asia-specific  cutoff points  or 
thresholds, which can capture the characteristics of Asian poverty more accurately. Particular 
attention will be paid to variables that are present in ADB DMCs but are missing in the datasets 
used by UNDP to obtain MPI estimates. 
 
13.  Determinants of inequality can be identified by traditional decomposition methods or 
recently  developed  regression-based  decomposition  techniques.  The  latter  can  attribute 
inequality  or  its  change  to  fundamental  causes  such  as  gender  discrimination,  sector 
segregation, and labor immobility. 6 
 
14.  The third component involves website construction, which will lead to improvement in 
transparency of and access to poverty and inequality estimates by ADB staff, DMCs, and 
external institutions and individuals. In addition to regular updates of poverty, inequality, and 
inclusive growth indicators, the website will publish cutting-edge knowledge products and user-
friendly tool kits for computation of poverty, inequality, and possibly vulnerability. 
 
15.  The TA will cover as many DMCs as data permit. The data required for poverty and 
inequality estimation can be in different forms. It is preferable to have access to household 
survey data. If not, income or expenditure data in grouped form can be used. If a DMC cannot 
provide data in these forms, it will be requested to provide poverty estimates based on the 
information  and  instructions  prepared  by  ADB.  Assistance  from  regional  departments  and 
resident missions will be needed. 
 
16.  Four workshops will be conducted: (i) a consultation workshop with representatives of 
DMCs on data availability issues where national statistical agencies will be requested to provide 
data or poverty estimates, (ii) a workshop to discuss poverty estimates and preliminary research 
findings where relevant government agencies will be consulted regarding the official release of 
the poverty estimates, (iii) a workshop to launch poverty estimates and the website, and (iv) a 
workshop to disseminate research findings. The participation of government representatives will 
be financed by this TA. No activities will be financed in any participating DMC unless a no-
objection is obtained from the government of such DMC. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $700,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB‘s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA. The TA will be implemented by ERDI for 
24 months, beginning in December 2012 until its targeted completion in December 2014. A 
poverty unit (or team) in ERD will be formed to manage and implement the TA. The poverty unit 
                                                
6 Guanghua Wan. 2004. Accounting for Income Inequality in Rural China: A Regression Based Approach. Journal of 
Comparative Economics. 32(2): pp.348–363.

4   
(or team) will tentatively have three international staff, one national staff, and one administrative 
staff. 
 
19.  ERDI will closely coordinate with regional departments, resident mission offices, the 
ADB Department of External Relations, and relevant national statistical systems, mostly for data 
access and dissemination activities. The poverty unit (or team) yet to be formally established will 
remain active after completion of the TA to sustain poverty and inequality estimation. ERDI will 
be working with external centers of excellence in poverty and inclusive growth research, such 
as the Institute for International Economic Policy at the George Washington University and the 
Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative at the University of Oxford. An advisory 
committee  will  be  established,  which  will  consist  of  experts  and  well-known  institutions 
specializing in poverty and inequality. For website development, ERDI will work with the ADB 
Office of Information Systems and Technology and the ADB Department of External Relations 
to ensure a user-friendly website and no duplication of websites. ERDI is coordinating with ADB 
Regional and Sustainable Development Department regarding the possible cross-linking or 
consolidation of existing poverty and poverty-related websites.  
 
20.  The TA is expected to finance up to 51 person-months of consulting services.7 This 
includes eight economists (international, 12 person-months) to conduct poverty- and inequality-
related research, one website development specialist (national, 6 person-months) to develop 
the website, and two research assistants (national, 24 person-months) to assist in the three 
components of the TA. These consultants will be recruited and engaged individually. In addition, 
a  consulting  firm  will  be  recruited  using  the  consultants‘  qualification  selection  method  to 
develop summary measures of inclusive growth and estimates of multidimensional poverty, and 
related  analysis  (9  person-months).  The  choice  of  the  consultants‘  qualification  selection 
method stems from a limited number of firms with the required expertise and experience in the 
field. In addition, the amount to be contracted is relatively small, so not many institutions are 
expected to be interested. The TA also provides for the participation of resource persons 
(2 person-months) who will provide technical inputs and guidance during the workshops. Each 
resource person assignment will not exceed 10 working days. 
 
21.  All consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The scope of work and outline 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The TA requires newly available 
individual or household level survey data. These survey datasets will be procured from DMC 
agencies as well as other recognized research agencies. Software will also be procured for the 
TA where needed. Procurement of data and software will be done in accordance with ADB‘s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursement will be done in 
accordance with ADB‘s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
22.  Major findings will be disseminated through websites, workshops, seminars, conferences, 
and  various  publications.  However,  before  the  official  release  of  the  poverty  estimates, 
consultations with various agencies will be done. In coordination with the ADB Department of 
External Relations, the project team will develop a dissemination and communications plan for 
                                                
7  Recruitment of individual consultants and the consulting firm will be done under the TA depending on the nature 
and scope of work and availability of expertise involved. Other than multidimensional poverty and summary 
measures of inclusive growth which will be contracted to a consulting firm, a wide range of poverty and inequality-
related research will be conducted under the TA such as vulnerability to poverty, chronic versus transient poverty, 
inequality, and decomposition. Given the diversity of topics and nature and scope of assignments, individual 
consultants are preferred.

5 
the  release  of  poverty  estimates  and  key  research  findings  in  the  early  stages  of  TA 
implementation. Evaluation will be based on knowledge products produced and the number of 
downloads and accesses to the proposed website. Review meetings by the TA team, including 
consultants, will be held to address constraints and monitor activities according to the schedule. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis for 
Addressing Knowledge and Statistical Gaps in Relation to Poverty Reduction, Inequality, and 
Inclusive Growth, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10            Appendix 3             
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Economists  (international,  8  consultants,  1.5  person-months  each,  intermittent  March 
2013–December 2014, 12 person-months total) 
1.  The  economists  should  each  have  a  doctoral  degree  in  economics  with  a  strong 
background  in  development  economics.  They  must  each  have  a  good  publication  record  on 
poverty, inequality, or related issues, preferably related to Asian economies. Quantitative and 
econometric skills are necessary. In particular, the consultants will 
(i)  conduct research and prepare background papers on issues related to poverty 
(vulnerability to poverty, chronic versus transient poverty, poverty decomposition), 
inequality  (inequality  decomposition,  non-income-based  inequality),  and  other 
related topics; 
(ii)  prepare  a  relevant  literature  review,  collect  and  compile  data,  and  conduct 
quantitative modeling using the latest techniques; 
(iii)  explore specific policies and interventions that are evidence-based;  
(iv)  prepare well-written paper(s) for publications; and 
(v)  participate in other activities related to the technical assistance (TA) project. 
 
B.  Website  development  specialist  (national,  1  consultant,  intermittent  April  2013–
December 2014, 6 person-months total) 
2.  The consultant should have (i) experience in designing websites and related educational 
background; (ii) excellent information technology (IT) skills and familiarity with Oracle and Java 
software; (iii) familiarity with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) IT architecture; (iv) familiarity with 
international websites and databases, particularly those related to statistics on poverty reduction or 
inequality; (v) the ability to document procedures and other important information, and excellent 
organizational  skills;  and  (vi)  work  experience  in  statistical  software  or  statistical  modeling, 
preferably. The consultant will carry out the following activities: 
(i)  review  existing  ADB  systems  to  identify  the  best  way  forward,  building  on  the 
existing infrastructure; 
(ii)  design and develop automated tools and IT architecture,; 
(iii)  design and develop the website in line with the specifications and strategy provided; 
(iv)  develop data visualization tools and other related tools; 
(v)  document the systems and procedures; and 
(vi)  perform other related tasks as assigned by the Development Indicators and Policy 
Research Division of the ADB Economics and Research Department. 
 
C.  Research Assistants (national, 2 consultants, March 2013–December 2014, 24 person-
months total) 
3.   The consultants should each have (i) a master‘s degree in economics, statistics, or a 
related field; (ii) experience working in the area of statistics or research and analysis; (iii) the 
technical and analytical skills required for the TA project; and (iv) proficiency in using statistical 
software for analysis such as Stata. The consultants will carry out the following activities: 
(i)  collect and compile data from different countries in developing Asia; 
(ii)  extract data from ADB TA project documents, and other relevant sources; 
(iii)  process survey data, generate analytical results, and organize these in tables and 
charts;

Appendix 3            11 
 
(iv)  draft  interpretations  of  analytical  results  and  explore  the  policy  implications  of 
analytical results; 
(v)  assist the team in other data processing requirements and/or literature reviews; 
(vi)  provide logistic and administrative support for project activities (e.g., workshops); 
and  
(vii)  perform other tasks relevant to the study or as may be assigned. 
 
D.  Consulting  Firm:  Inclusive  Growth  and  Multidimensional  Poverty  Analysis 
(international, intermittent, March 2013–December 2014, 9 person-months total) 
 
4.  A consulting firm will be recruited to conduct inclusive growth and multidimensional poverty 
research. The firm must have sufficient experience in the relevant areas and be well-regarded in 
the development community. The consulting firm will specifically undertake to 
(i)  refine  and  consolidate  methods  for  measuring  inclusive  growth  and 
multidimensional poverty, 
(ii)  produce guidance and tools for applying the methods developed, 
(iii)  develop  summary  measures  of  inclusive  growth  and  estimates  of  the 
multidimensional poverty index for developing member countries in Asia and the 
Pacific, and 
(iv)  produce research papers and other related outputs. 
 
5.  These tasks will require the following: 
 
(i)  A  team  leader  (international,  1.5  person-months,  intermittent),  who  must  be  a 
leading  authority  on  poverty  issues,  with  an  outstanding  publication  record  on 
poverty measurement, will (a) provide overall intellectual leadership for the activities 
and serve as a focal point for ADB and other researchers, and (b) write central 
components of the research and provide overall quality control for the research 
outputs. 
(ii)  An economist (international, 1.5 person-months, intermittent) will (a) draft part of the 
research papers, review other research products, and contribute to the compilation 
of research outputs; and (b) support the principal investigator in coordinating and 
overseeing project activities. 
(iii)  An assistant director (international, 3 person-months, intermittent) will (a) assist in 
organizing  workshops  and  managing  travel,  payments,  and  reimbursements; 
(b) manage the economist and research assistant; and (c) assist the team leader in 
planning and reporting tasks. 
(iv)  A  research  assistant  (international,  3  person-months,  intermittent)  will  provide 
technical  assistance  for  the  empirical  dimensions  of  the  research,  including 
identifying  datasets,  carrying  out  econometric  analyses,  and  drafting  reports  of 
results.
